item.description:
Is anyone interested in attending Hub on Wheels? This is event has been running for 8 years thus far and still continues to be popular among many biking enthusiasts. I will not be attending but Norm said he would take on the task of 'santa' (inside joke), a fine leader if I do say myself.

http://www.bostonbikes.org/events/hub-on-wheels/

Experience a car-free Storrow Drive, explore historic neighborhoods, and take in views of the Boston Harbor that you’ve never seen before.
The ride starts and finishes on City Hall Plaza in downtown Boston, with three different routes to choose from: 10, 30 and 50 miles.

You can sign up on their website. The Registration Fee is $45.

Please note:
Hub on Wheels is presented by Mayor Menino’s Office of Special Events in cooperation with Boston Bikes.
The ride is� fully supported and safe, with three routes:� 10, 30, or 50 miles of harbor views and hidden pathways, river greenways and Boston’s wonderful and eclectic neighborhoods.� Storrow Drive is completely car-free, as is the entire 10 mile route. To reopen Storrow Drive in a timely fashion, anyone not reaching the 10 mile turnaround by 9:30 will be turned back early. Many other roads are open to traffic.
Marshals along all routes make sure there’s plenty of space to ride.� Tech support and ride snacks are free of charge. All rules of the road apply. Please ride safely and courteously.

Riding with children: Cyclists must be 10+ years to ride the 10 mile loop, 12+ years to ride the longer loops. Children under 10 may participate only if riding with an adult on a tandem, trail-a-bike, bike seat or trailer. Children under 10 ride for free — no separate registration is required. Anyone under 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

http://www.hubonwheels.org/

PARKING: Everyone receives a coupon for $4 parking at the Government Center Garage [www.governmentcentergarage.com] as part of their registration packet. If you carry your bicycles on top of your car, you must remove them before entering the garage. There will be a designated area to do so.
GETTING THERE: City Hall Plaza, Boston, 02201. Closest bike-accessible T stops are Charles St. (Red), Haymarket (Green and Orange) and State Street (Blue). Bikes are allowed on Sundays on all MBTA commuter rail and subway lines except green and silver. Some MBTA buses are now equipped with bike racks.

Please connect with Norm with any further information on how to meet and where to meet, etc. I don't know if he likes separate emails for questions or suggestions but start with posting here so everyone can be on the same page.

SCHEDULE:

6:30 a.m. – 7:45 a.m. Registration & Packet Pick Up

7:45 a.m.

Opening Ceremony at Start/Finish Stage

8:00 a.m. Ride Starts!
item.name: Boston's Hub on Wheels
